content: "http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/nyregion/20recruit.html?ref=education" I understand the privacy concerns parents may have, but I would hope recruiters would not be passing the information out to identity thieves. It really just sounds like another case of parents and schools horrified at the thought that THEIR kids should be asked to serve in the military. EVERYONE should be asked to serve. We should simply quit focusing so much on high schools and focus on junior colleges and worksites where helicopter parents are (somewhat) less likely to bar military recruiters from approaching. Though I know even colleges will often ban recruiting due to the don't ask/don't tell policy. Sigh. What do y'all think?
reply: "http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/nyregion/20recruit.html?ref=education" I understand the privacy concerns parents may have, but I would hope recruiters would not be passing the information out to identity thieves. Though I know even colleges will often ban recruiting due to the don't ask/don't tell policy. Sigh. What do y'all think?
title: Recruiting

content: During a war every parent is scared. High school are chosen because they are the world's cross road's it allows grad's to pick there own choice go to college etc. if you only go to Jr colleges etc you are limiting the process some what from what you could be getting by helping HS grad's by giving them a wider option then just work or college.

content: I love how colleges want recruiters off the campus yet still want all that awesome federal money. I'm so angry that even made it to the Supreme Court.
reply: I love how colleges want recruiters off the campus yet still want all that awesome federal money. I'm so angry that even made it to the Supreme Court.
title: Recruiting

content: I have no problem banning military recruiters from school campuses. However I believe any school that bans military recruiters should be made to have to ban all recruiters and that includes sports and college recruiters as well. Let's even get rid of high school guidance counselors afterall they often "sway" students into colleges as well. What I love is the fact that it is the parents who want the military not to hassle their kids, yet it is these same people who do the damned b*tchING and moaning the first time a natural disaster strikes their area. Where are the National Guard they ask etc. Well guess what there is no more National Guard they couldn't get anyone to join thanks to your efforts!!!!. So I would suggest that not only the schools not receive federal funding but the CITIES AND TOWNS where such schools are located also not receive federal funding nor any type of federal assistance when disasters (ie fires, blackouts, riots, blizzards etc) hit their areas.
